Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/016.
references.B77GAI01USGP: Gaines, D. 1977. Birds of the Yosemite Sierra. California Syllabus, Oakland. 153pp
references.R81GAR01USGP: Garrett, K. and J. Dunn. 1981. Birds of southern California: status and distribution. Los Angeles Audubon Soc. Los Angeles, CA.
references.A80KUB01USGP: Kuban, J. F. and R. L. Neill. 1980. Feeding ecology of hummingbirds in the highlands of the Chisos Mountains, Texas. Condor 82:180-185.
references.A74JOH01USGP: Johnson, N. K., and K. L. Garrett. 1974. Interior bird species expand breeding ranges into southern California. West. Birds 5:45-56.
references.A68LIG01USGP: Ligon, J.D. and R.P. Balda. 1968. Recent data on summer birds of the Chiricahua Mountains area, southeastern Arizona. Transactions of the San Diego Society of Natural History 15 (5): 41-50.

references.B64PHI01NAUS: Phillips, A., J. Marshall, and G. Monson. 1964. The Birds of Arizona. The University of Arizona Press, Tucson, AZ.
references.A44GRI01USGP: Grinnell, J. and A. H. Miller. 1944. The distribution of the birds of California. Pac. Coast Avifauna no. 27. Cooper Ornithol. Club, Berkeley, CA.

habitat_description:
Northwest/Southwest:
This species occupies the Upper Sonoran, Transition, and Boreal zones. In California it is known to inhabit the upper Sonoran belt of piñon (Pinus monophylla), juniper (Juniperus californica), and mountain mahogany (Cercocarpus spp.), in vicinity of thickets of willow (Salix spp.) and Garrya, along wet or dry stream courses (Grinnell and Miller 1944). In Arizona: Transition and Boreal (Canadian and Hudsonian) of higher mountains; found in Pinus ponderosa, oaks (Quercus spp.), Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga taxifolia), spruce (Picea engelmanni) and fir (Abies concolor, A. lasiocarpa) throughout e. and n. Arizona, also some in riparian upper Sonoran (Phillips et al. 1964). In the Chiricahua Mountains of AZ, Ligon and Balda  (1968) suggest this species is “uncommon” oak and oak-juniper woodlands, but “common” in riparian canyon and coniferous forests. In Texas: (Chisos Mts., Kuban and Neill 1980): cypress-pine-oak (Cupressus-Pinus-Quercus) and pinyon-juniper-oak (Pinus cembroides-Juniperus deppeana-Quercus) associations. In Colorado: foothills and mountains and montane valleys throughout state: Transition, Canadian and Hudsonian zones. Males fly over and forage on higher mountains. Nests to at least 3,230 m. Utah, Wyoming: aspen (Populus tremuloides), ponderosa pine, engelmann spruce, subalpine fir (Abies lasiocarpa), and Douglas fir (quoted directly from Calder and Calder 1992).
A fairly common summer resident of southern California, breeding in the higher mountains of the northern deserts. Occurs primarily in open stands of montane riparian, montane chaparral (mountain mahogany), pinyon-juniper, and mixed conifer habitats. Nesting takes place in the White, Panamint, Grapevine, Kingston, and Clark Mts. (Garrett and Dunn 1981), and in the Inyo Mts. (Grinnell and Miller 1944). It is suspected in other Mojave Desert ranges. Recent records from the eastern slope of the Sierra Nevada, north into Mono Co., suggest that the breeding range has expanded (Johnson and Garrett 1974, Gaines 1977b).  A few recent records from northern California (McCaskie et al. 1988)(quoted directly from Zeiner et al. 1990 via Granholm et  al.).
